column4: hallo! I seem to be having a bit of an issue -- I have  GeForce4MX4000, running 7.03, and I believe the nVidia driver is loaded, but I can't get beyond 1024x768x50hz
You mean, you can't get any higher refresh rate?  That's a deliberate (but _stupid_) feature of the nvidia drivers.
I can't get a higher resolution either
They mis-report the refresh rate (and use it for TwinView - your first monitor is 50hz, second is 51Hz, etc)
It's being reported in the system --> preferences --> screen resolution panel, is there a different place to configure the nvidia driver properly?
Well, running "nvidia-settigns" from a terminal will allow you to change the refresh rate, yes.
well, that explains why I'm not dying of flicker with a 50hz refresh rate, becasue it's not really 50hz :P
any idea why I can't seem to get above 1024x768?
Yup, indeed.  How did you install the drivers?
I just installed my system about an hour ago, this is my first foray into graphical linux :P I was poking around the system preferences, and went to system --> preferences --> desktop effects
Ah, and it fired up the "Restricted Manager", yes?

it told me to install the invidia driver, and gave me two buttons, "install" or "cancel." I clicked install, it asked me for my password, did the install in it's beautiful idiot proof manner, then told me to reboot and run desktop effects again.
There was a bug in the pre-release version of Feisty (Ubuntu 7.04) where the restricted manager would incorrectly write the wrong resolutions to xorg.conf.
after the reboot, it brought up the restricted driver manager, which says it's loaded and hunky dory.
But if you're using the full release, I thought that was fixed.  However, it should be easy to fix.
okay, so the section I want is "You use the "nvidia" driver (Binary drivers)
There should have been a suggestion to run the command "sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg" in that link, right?  That should fix your problem (when you select the right set of resolutions)
upon the edit of xorg.conf, do I need to reboot?
